Formal methods are a systematic approach to the specification, design, development, testing, and maintenance of software and systems. They provide a rigorous way to reason about the behavior of a system, using mathematical or symbolic techniques to describe the system's properties and requirements. Formal methods can be used to ensure that a system meets its specifications and behaves as intended, and can be particularly useful in safety-critical or mission-critical systems where mistakes or failures can have serious consequences.

The Latin American Workshop on Formal Methods (available at <https://arxiv.org/abs/1401.0564>) brings together researchers working in formal methods and related areas such as automated analysis. It provides a venue for Latin American researchers working in these areas to promote their interaction and collaboration.

Empirical studies on formal methods and tools are rare. In a paper titled "Empirical Formal Methods: Guidelines for Performing Empirical Studies on Formal Methods" (available at <https://arxiv.org/abs/2208.05266>), Maurice H. ter Beek and Alessio Ferrari provide guidelines for such studies. They mention their main ingredients and then define nine different study strategies, discussing the crucial characteristics, difficulties, and challenges of applying them to formal methods and tools.

A Manifesto for Applicable Formal Methods (available at <https://arxiv.org/abs/2112.12758>) by Mario Gleirscher and Jaco van de Pol and Jim Woodcock suggests that formal methods still need to be made more applicable and ready for their intended use, particularly in critical domains where they have the greatest potential. The authors lay out a set of principles that, when followed by a formal method, give rise to its mature applicability in a given scope.

Rooting Formal Methods within Higher Education Curricula for Computer Science and Software Engineering (available at <https://arxiv.org/abs/2010.05708>) advocates for improved teaching of formal methods, systematic highlighting of formal methods within existing courses, and the inclusion of a compulsory formal methods course in computer science and software engineering curricula. These recommendations are based on the observations that formal methods are an essential and cost-effective means to increase software quality, but computer science and software engineering programmes typically fail to provide adequate training in formal methods.

The statement "1 + 2 is equal to 3" is a basic mathematical truth. This concept can be extended to positive integers represented as arithmetic series, where positive integers can be expressed as the sum of other positive integers. This idea is explored in an article named "On Positive Integers Represented as Arithmetic Series" (available at <https://arxiv.org/abs/0806.4471>) written by Dimitris Sardelis. The article highlights the connections between the multiplicative and additive properties of positive integers when represented as arithmetic series. The author investigates the representation of positive integers as sums of successive odd positive numbers or even positive numbers.

A related concept is the use of sumterms and summands in the meta-arithmetic of summation. In an article named "Sumterms, Summands, Sumtuples, and Sums and the Meta-arithmetic of Summation" (available at <https://arxiv.org/abs/2009.08851>) written by Jan A. Bergstra, sumterms are introduced as syntactic entities, and summands are introduced as semantic entities. The author provides a new description of the notion of a sum as a role that can be played by a number. Sumterm splitting operators are introduced, and the author discusses the sum splitting paradox.

Another aspect of sums is the structure of sets which have coinciding representation functions. In an article named "On the structure of sets which have coinciding representation functions" (available at <https://arxiv.org/abs/1702.04499>) written by Sándor Z. Kiss and Csaba Sándor, the authors partially describe the structure of sets of non-negative integers that have coinciding representation functions.

Finally, a new general and unified method of summation is introduced in an article named "On a new general method of summation" (available at <https://arxiv.org/abs/1105.2787>) written by Armen Bagdasaryan. The method is based on the idea of reordering integers and leads to a number of explicit and closed-form summation formulas. The author also assigns limits to certain unbounded or oscillating functions and briefly discusses future research directions.

The papers listed all investigate different topics. The first paper, titled "Coding Reliability with Aclus -- Did I correctly characterize my observations?" by Marcus Weber and Oguzhan Y\"ur\"uk, explores the automatic checking of binary data sets for inconsistencies and the finding of logical rules valid for the analyzed objects. The second paper, "Fractions in the Suan Shu Shu (China, Beginning of the 2nd Century BCE)" by R\'emi Anicotte, examines the 301 instances of regular expressions for fractions found in the Suan Shu Shu, providing a complete description of their diversity. The third paper, "A note on avoidable words in squarefree ternary words" by Narad Rampersad, completely characterizes the words that can be avoided in infinite squarefree ternary words. The fourth paper, "A Transformational Decision Procedure for Non-Clausal Propositional Formulas" by Alexander Sakharov, presents a decision procedure for detecting valid propositional formulas based on the Davis-Putnam method, with plenty of optimizations based on calculation of delta-sets.
